Soil does NOT remain in ball when squeezed Place approximately 25 g soil in palm. Add water dropwise and knead the soil to break down all aggregates. Soil is at the proper consistency when plastic and moldable, like moist putty.
Is too dry The soil sample is too dry.
NO RESULT: Add more water and start again
Is too wet The soil sample is too wet.
NO RESULT: Add dry soil and start again NO RESULT: add dry soil to soak up water
NOT too wet nor too dry The soil is NOT too wet nor too dry.
Sand A sand has a loose gritty feel and does not stick together. Individual sand grains can be seen or felt. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

Soil remains in ball when squeezed Place approximately 25 g soil in palm. Add water dropwise and knead the soil to break down all aggregates. Soil is at the proper consistency when plastic and moldable, like moist putty.
TASK: Roll ribbon Rub a ball of soil between thumb and forefinger to make a 'ribbon'
Does NOT form a ribbom A 'ribbon' is NOT formed when a ball of soil is rubbed between thumb and forefinger.
Loamy Sand In a loamy sand particles barely stick together and a moulded piece of soil just holds its shape. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Forms ribbon A 'ribbon' is formed when a ball of soil is rubbed between thumb and forefinger.
Medium ribbon (2.5-5cm long) The ribbon formed when a ball of soil is rubbed between thumb and forefinger is between 2.5 and 5cm long.
TASK: Wet soil and rub with forefinger Excessively wet a small pinch of soil in palm and rub with forefinger.
Does NOT feel very gritty The wetted soil does NOT feel very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Feels very smooth The wetted soil feels very smooth when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Silty Clay Loam A silty clay loam is like a clay loam but silty as well and smooth to the touch. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Neither very gritty nor very smooth The wetted soil does NOT feel very smooth nor very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Clay Loam More easily moulded into a shape than a loam, a clay loam rolls out to a thin ribbon between the palms while a loam will break-up. When dry a clay loam will form a lump but is not as tough to break as a clay.(VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Feels very gritty The wetted soil feels very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Sandy Clay Loam A sandy clay loam is like a clay loam but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam) (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Strong ribbon The ribbon formed when a ball of soil is rubbed between thumb and forefinger is strong and over 5cm long.
TASK: Wet soil and rub with forefinger Excessively wet a small pinch of soil in palm and rub with forefinger.
Does NOT feel very gritty The wetted soil does NOT feel very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Feels very smooth The wetted soil feels very smooth when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Silty Clay A silty clay is like a clay but smoother. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Neither very gritty nor very smooth The wetted soil does NOT feel very smooth nor very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Clay Clays are tough and can be moulded into shapes when moist. Clays form a long flexible ribbon when rubbed between the palms and the ribbon can often be bent into a U shape without breaking. Clays dry into very hard clods. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Feels very gritty The wetted soil feels very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Sandy Clay A sandy clay is like a clay but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam). (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Weak ribbon (<2.5cm long) The ribbon formed when a ball of soil is rubbed between thumb and forefinger is less than 2.5cm long.
TASK: Wet soil and rub with forefinger Excessively wet a small pinch of soil in palm and rub with forefinger.
Does NOT feel very gritty The wetted soil does NOT feel very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Feels very smooth The wetted soil feels very smooth when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Silt Loam A silty loam is like a loam but has a smooth silky feel when a moist sample is pushed between the index finger and thumb. On drying a sample can form a hard lump but this may be broken by hand. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Neither very gritty nor very smooth The wetted soil does NOT feel very smooth nor very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Loam A loam breaks into crumbs but will tend to stick together. Sand grains cannot be felt in a moist sample which when squeezed will retain its shape when handled freely. Loams are usually soft to the feel. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
Feels very gritty The wetted soil feels very gritty when rubbed on the palm and with forefinger.
Sandy Loam A sandy loam sticks together more than a loamy sand but can be easily broken. Individual sand grains can be felt and heard if a wet sample is rubbed between the index finger and thumb and held close to the ear. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
